thread.title: What's the catch? Terrific tuna caught in the Bahamas
thread.title_full: What's the catch? Terrific tuna caught in the Bahamas

title: What's the catch? Terrific tuna caught in the Bahamas
text:
What's the catch? Terrific tuna caught in the Bahamas | Published on October 14, 2015 Head out past the seaweed line with us to catch some fish! These images were provided by the Bahamas Sport Fishing Network, find more info at bahamassportfishingnetworks.com, or at #BSFNpics. Jayson Rathmann Ready to cast a line? Yellowfin Tuna are prized by sport fishermen. This one was caught just off the coast of San Salvador, Bahamas. Arnund Lemaire Yellowfin Tuna are among the largest species of tuna, reaching weights of up to 400 pounds! This one was caught near Cherokee, Abaco. Chris Rees Sushi, anyone? This 60 lb Yellowfin Tuna was snared near Abaco, Bahamas. Chris Rees Exhausted but proud! This 93 lb Yellowfin Tuna was brought in off the coast of Grand Bahama. Jevon Russell This 100 lb Yellowfin Tuna was caught in Green Turtle Cay, Abaco. Tyler Survance This tuna is a whopper at 120 lbs! It was caught with no small amount of effort off the coast of Nassau, Bahamas. Teddy Pratt "Eye" see you! This big bad yellowfin tuna was caught off the coast of the Bahamas. Kai Survance The Yellowfin Tuna gets its name from the bright, neon yellow color of the second dorsal fin and the anal fin, as well as the finlets between those fins and the tail. Local Boy Charters Abaco Yellowfin tuna have been known to grow to more than seven feet long! Chang Sien Chin Three friends demonstrate just how big their catch is! Keith Kelty Talk about a haul! This gorgeous gaff shot happened near Spanish Wells, Bahamas. James Dunnam This cool underwater shot shows what it looks like when a tuna is hooked! Jayson Rathmann Bad weather? What bad weather? This die-hard fisherman is rewarded for his dedication near Bahama Palm Shores, Abaco. Chris Rees Some fishermen swear that fishing at night remains the best time to hook and land the biggest tuna. David Rees Blackfin Tuna are one of the smaller tuna species, but they still pack some heft at up to 46 lbs each! John Sullivan A Girl and Her Tuna: A Love Story. Brought to you by Bahamas Sport Fishing Network from the depths of Treasure Cay, Abaco. Kaitlyn Ziegler What's more fun than going fishing after school and catching a Yellowfin Tuna almost as big as you are? Dawson Thompson Talk about a haul! How many trophy-sized Yellowfin Tuna can you count in this pic (hint: it's in the double digits!) Keith Kelty Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide 
Looking for a fish with some fight? Many anglers claim that these tuna are, pound for pound, the strongest and fastest trophy fish out there. The Bahamas Sport Fishing Network shows off the biggest and baddest of their catches in the slideshow above. Think you can do better? Head out past the seaweed line, set your rod and reel and make sure you've got a gaff close at hand! 
How about something with a little more color? You won't believe how gorgeous these MONSTER mahi-mahi are! To catch the best Mahi-mahi, you have to head out past the seaweed line in the Bahamas. These images were provided by the Bahamas Sport Fishing Network, find more info at bahamassportfishingnetworks.com, or at #BSFNpics. Chang Chin Can you spot the Mahi on the run in this picture? Chang Chin He's got the Mahi-mahi on the line, the fight is on! Chang Chin A colorful Mahi-mahi fish fights the line in its mouth in the Bahamas. Chang Chin A spectacularly colored Mahi-mahi fights and splashes above the ocean in the Bahamas. Chang Chin The amazing colors of the Mahi are displayed as it's pulled above the water's surface. Chang Chin After a long battle, Trevor shows off the Mahi he landed. Chang Chin Chang pulls another Mahi onto the boat and into the cooler for safekeeping. Chang Chin Bagging Mahi isn't a walk in the park -- you have to be on the lookout for the tiger sharks that come looking for their share of the fish! Chang Chin A proud fisherman shows off his speared catch. Chang Chin Travis takes the chance to show off his beard and his fresh-caught Mahi. Travis Kelly How's this for a new superhero?! The Masked Mahi Man. David Rees So many Mahi! Also known as common dolphinfish, these monsters weigh in at about 15-29 pounds on average! Chris Thompson They can definitely grow larger than that, however. Here a fisherman shows off his massive catch -- a huge 60lb Bull Mahi caught off Nassau, Bahamas. Swanko Pinder Knife and Mahi in hand, ready for cleaning! These fish are super fast, swimming up to 57.5 mph! Chris Thompson Fishing in the Bahamas can be a productive outing, catching Mahi by the cartload! Chang Chin Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide 
Got a need for speed? Sharpen your spears for a little wahoo madness down in the Bahamas. Head out past the seaweed line with us to catch some truly enormous Wahoo fish! These images were provided by the Bahamas Sport Fishing Network, find more info at bahamassportfishingnetworks.com, or at #BSFNpics. Kai Survance Ready your spears! The Wahoo fish is prized by sports fishermen. This one was caught near Hope Town, Abaco in the Bahamas. Corey Engle The Wahoo is covered with small, scarcely visible scales; the back is an iridescent blue, while the sides are silvery, with a pattern of irregular vertical blue bars. This one was caught near Cherokee Point, Abaco in the Bahamas. Chris Rees Watch the teeth when you pull in your Wahoo... they're razor sharp! This one was caught in Green Turtle Cay, Abaco, in the Bahamas. Bronson Russell The Wahoo is sometimes confused with the Barracuda, but they are two different species, with the latter having larger, more visible scales. This Wahoo was caught â€“ Schooner Bay, Abaco June Russell Wahoo are MASSIVE fish, with some recorded as more than 8 feet long. This one was caught right near Grand Bahama Island. Alexa Borrego These big fish can weigh up to 183 pounds! Talk about heavy lifting! This one was caught in Green Cay, New Providence, in the Bahamas. Shayne Johnson Wahoo grow very quickly. One tagged by researchers grew from 11 to 33 pounds in one year! This one was caught near North Exuma in the Bahamas. Chang Chin Wahoo are prized by sport fishermen because they are some of the fastest fish in the sea. This one was caught off of South Andros in the Bahamas. Scott Thompson Despite their massive size, Wahoo can swim up to 60 miles per hour! This one was caught off of South Andros in the Bahamas. Ashley Brown The Wahoo isfound worldwide in tropical and subtropical seas. This one was caught in SanSalvador in the Bahamas. Arnaud Lemaire The Wahoo's wide geographical distribution has lead to it having multiple names.InHawaii, the wahoo is known asono.This one was caught off of Cherokee Point, Abaco in the Bahamas. David Rees Many Hispanic areas of theCaribbeanandCentral Americarefer to the Wahoo aspeto. This one was caught in Winding Bay, Abaco in the Bahamas. David Rees What better way to spend the holidays than in the Bahamas, fishing for massive Wahoo fish?! This one was caught south of New Providence in the Bahamas. Rachel Lightbourne Graham Wahoo fish are great for cooking, and are prized by many gourmets. This one was caught near Hole In The Wall, Abaco in the Bahamas. Travis Kelly The flesh of the Wahoo fish can range from white to grey, and delicate to dense. This one was caught in Green Cay, New Providence, in the Bahamas. Shayne Johnson If you're curious, the taste is similar to mackerel, but slightly less pronounced. This Wahoo fish was caught just inside Little Harbour, Abaco in the Bahamas. David Rees Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay
